summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by DOJ OIG Senior Special Agent with a BOP Lieutenant regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein and surrounding circumstances at MCC New York. The interview focuses on the lieutenant's role, duties, knowledge of Epstein's cellmate requirements, rounds and counts in the SHU, and events leading up to Epstein's death on August 10, 2019.

persons.context: High-profile inmate who died by suicide in MCC SHU on August 10, 2019. The interview extensively discusses his housing, cellmate requirements, and supervision.

connections.description: Reyes was Epstein's cellmate in the SHU until he was removed for court on August 9, 2019, and did not return.
Tartaglione was Epstein's initial cellmate before his July 23 suicide attempt.
Both were correctional officers working together in the SHU on the shifts leading up to Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's first suicide attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein attempted suicide in his cell at MCC by putting something around his neck. He was then placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Epstein removed from suicide watch
events.description: Epstein was taken off psych observation/suicide watch and an email was sent stating he needed to be housed with an appropriate cellmate in the SHU.

events.title: Reyes removed from MCC
events.description: Inmate Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, went to court and was designated WAB (With All Belongings), indicating he likely would not return. Epstein was left without a cellmate.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein found dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell in the MCC SHU, having died by suicide.

events.title: OIG Interview of BOP Lieutenant
events.description: DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary sworn interview with a BOP Lieutenant at FCI Danbury regarding Epstein's death and circumstances at MCC.

locations: Federal Correctional Institution Danbury, Danbury, Connecticut
keyFacts: The lieutenant confirms Epstein was required to have a cellmate for three reasons: 1) He was in the SHU (where inmates are generally double-bunked), 2) He was on the 'hot list' due to his suicide attempt, and 3) An email was sent on July 30, 2019, stating he needed a cellmate after coming off suicide watch.

The lieutenant states that rounds and counts in the SHU on August 9-10, 2019, appear to have been falsified or not properly conducted, based on discrepancies in count slips and Els shown during the interview.
The lieutenant believes Epstein's death was primarily due to failure to conduct proper 30-minute rounds and counts, not solely the lack of a cellmate, though both were factors.
The lieutenant had personal interaction with Epstein when he was on suicide watch, taking him to showers and speaking with him about why he was there.

The interview reveals systemic issues at MCC including severe understaffing, mandated overtime, and difficulties in hiring and retention, which the lieutenant suggests contributed to operational failures.
